III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4150 Incident reporting
Section (3) If an institution determines that a youth is absent without legal
Description permission, then the institution shall immediately report the
information to law enforcement, the parent/legal guardian or next
of kin, the licensing authority, and the referring agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 8/19/25, a youth went AWOL from a facility and went to a
relative's home. The facility was notified by family on 8/25/25 of
the youth's whereabouts and the facility failed to notify the foster
care agency of this information. There are concerns facility did not
report the AWOL until 8/20/25 to the foster care team.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via phone on August
27, 2025. Foster Care Supervisor reported she was notified by
Foster Care Worker the facility did not report Youth A going
AWOL on August 19, 2025, until the following day. She reported
the facility was provided with contact information for the after-
hours foster care team to be informed of this information, but they
never used it. Foster Care Supervisor reported Youth A had gone
AWOL multiple times at the facility, but it was for less than a few
hours and he would always return. She reported the facility stated
that, although Youth A did return for a brief period on August 21,
2025, they were not counting that as a full return and the five-day
bed hold was still in place. Foster Care Supervisor reported since
Youth A did not return within those five days, he was discharged
from the facility on August 23, 2025. She reported the facility was
notified on August 25, 2025, that Youth A was with a relative, and
they never contacted Foster Care Worker to update her on the
location of Youth A. Foster Care Supervisor reported she is
concerned the facility is failing to communicate clearly about these
incidents.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone on August 27,
2025. Foster Care Worker reported Youth A would be reported
AWOL multiple times at the facility but was only gone for a short
amount of time. She reported Case Manager reported to her in the
mid-morning on August 20, 2025, that Youth A went AWOL the
night before. Foster Care Worker reported she did not know why it
took so long to report this to her. She reported this is the first time
Youth A has gone overnight from the facility. Foster Care Worker
reported when she was notified of the AWOL, she was also told by
Administrator 1 that if he did not return within five days, then his
2

bed would be closed, and he could not return to the facility. She
reported she believed that date was August 23, 2025. Foster Care
Worker confirmed all the contacts within Youth A’s MiSACWIS
case were correct. She reported she was very concerned about
Youth A’s safety, and she contacted Relative on August 26, 2025,
to see if she had heard from Youth A. Foster Care Worker
reported Relative reported Youth A was at her home since the
night of August 24, 2025. She reported Relative told her she
contacted Case Manager on August 25, 2025, at the facility, who
said Youth A was discharged, and she was going to call Foster
Care Worker about Youth A being with Relative. Foster Care
Worker reported she was never notified by anyone at the facility
about this information which concerned her.
Case Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on
August 28, 2025. Case Manager reported she worked with Youth
A when he was placed at the facility. She reported she was
present when Youth A went AWOL on August 19, 2025. Case
Manager reported she followed the facility’s AWOL policy, where
she notified the administration team, contacted law enforcement,
contacted the National Center for Exploited Children Hotline, and
completed the incident report. She reported Administrator 1 will
then send out the incident report to the youth’s foster care team
within 24 hours to notify them of the AWOL. Case Manager
reported this is the first time Youth A has been gone for more than
a couple of hours. She reported Youth A would leave the home to
go AWOL when he became frustrated at the home or wanted to
use substances. Case Manager reported Youth A was discharged
after five days of being gone from the facility. She reported Youth
A returned to the home for a couple of hours during that period,
and Foster Care Worker was notified of this. Case Manager
reported Youth A only stayed for an hour and was gone again, so
the five-day bed hold remained in place. She reported on August
25, 2025, she received a call from Relative that Youth A was
currently at her home, and Case Manager explained to Relative
that Youth A was discharged from their program. Case Manager
reported when she got off the phone with Relative, she called
Foster Care Worker to notify her. She showed this consultant the
call log from her cell phone that she used to call Foster Care
Worker, which verified a call was placed.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
August 28, 2025. Administrator 1 reported the facility’s policy for
AWOL youth is that staff are to report immediately to the
administration team, law enforcement, the National Center for
Exploited Children Hotline, and then complete an incident report.
3

She reported she then received the incident report and sent it to
state licensing and the foster care team within 24 hours.
Administrator 1 reported this is what happened with Youth A when
he went AWOL on August 19, 2025. She reported when she sent
the incident report, she also sent the information about the five-
day bed hold, and if he was not to return within those five days, he
would then be discharged from the program. Administrator 1
reported that since Youth A did not fully return within those five
days, he was discharged from the program. She reported an email
was sent out on the morning of August 24, 2025, stating Youth A
was discharged. Administrator 1 reported the relative did contact
Case Manager about Youth A’s whereabouts, and since Youth A
was discharged, Case Manager called Foster Care Worker to
notify her. Consultant asked Administrator 1 if she was aware that,
within state licensing rules, when a youth is considered AWOL,
the facility needs to report immediately to law enforcement,
guardian, foster care team, and state licensing, and she reported
she was not aware that it needed to be immediately reported to
state licensing and the foster care team. Administrator 1 thought
she had 24 hours from the incident to report.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
August 28, 2025. Administrator 2 verified her understanding of
the facility’s AWOL reporting policy and noted that state licensing
and foster care team needed to be notified within 24 hours of the
incident. She reported for the incident with Youth A, all the internal
protocols were followed with their internal reporting standards, bed
hold information, and discharge planning.
Administrator 3 was interviewed via phone on August 29,
2025. Administrator 3 reported Youth A struggled within their
program, as though he had a low IQ; he was still a higher-
functioning youth than what they typically work with. She reported
she had concerns with Youth A’s substance use and feels that it
needs to be addressed. Administrator 3 reported this information
has been clearly communicated to the foster care team for Youth
A. She reported Youth A would leave the facility for a couple of
hours and use substances and then come back. Administrator 3
reported staff followed all the policies and procedures as it came
to reporting Youth A being AWOL, communicating with Foster
Care Worker, and discharging Youth A from their program. She
reported she was not aware that the rule had changed to have to
report to all parties about an AWOL youth immediately.
Administrator 3 reported there is also no definition of immediately
in the rule set, so within her interpretation, then within 24 hours
would be appropriate for state licensing and the foster care team
4

to receive notification, as long as law enforcement and the
National Center for Exploited Children Hotline were contacted
immediately to assist with making sure this youth is safe. She
reported this policy has been reviewed and approved by state
licensing. Administrator 3 did take feedback from this consultant
about the understanding of the rule and is open to updating their
practice to be in compliance with the rule set.
Documentation Reviewed:
- Youth A’s MiSACWIS case file- Social work contacts
were reviewed in Youth A’s
o August 20, 2025 11:13am- Foster Care Worker
received a call from Case Manager stating Youth A
went AWOL last night and has not returned.
o August 20, 2025 2:38pm- Foster Care Worker
called the facility to see any MiSACWIS case file to
verify the communication between the facility and
foster care team. The following contacts were
reviewed on August 27, 2025: Updates on Youth A.
It was noted that a relative contacted the facility
stating they saw Youth A at the local library.
o August 21, 2025 10:10am- Foster Care Worker was
contacted by the facility stating Youth A came back
this morning to the house but expressed wanting to
leave again.
o August 21, 2025 11:13am- Foster Care Worker was
contacted by Case Manager stating Youth A did
come back to shower and then he left the home
again.
o August 21, 2025 1:00pm- FTM was held with foster
care team, placement unit, and the facility. It was
discussed that the facility submitted a 30-day move
notice with the request to move Youth A by
08/27/2025.
- Facility Incident report #109 dated August 19, 2025 at
6:57pm completed by Case Manager- The report notes
Youth A went AWOL from the facility on August 19, 2025,
at 5:40pm. The report notes Youth A stated he wanted to
leave because he had “business to handle.” Youth A
reported he was leaving and he would be back shortly.
Staff tried to encourage alternative decision making. Law
5

Enforcement and National Center Exploited Children
Hotline (NCMEC) were contacted to complete missing
person’s report. Case Manager noted in the report, Youth A
was given the option to notify his worker, guardian and/or
support person regarding the incident and Youth A chose
not to contact anyone. Within the report, Case Manager,
noted Administrative Team and On Call person for the
facility were notified of the incident.
- Email from Administrator 2 dated September 2, 2025-
Administrator 2 emailed this consultant reporting the
incident report #109 from Youth A’s AWOL on August 19,
2025, was never emailed out by Administrator 1. She
reported there was only the phone call made by Case
Manager to Foster Care Worker on August 20, 2025,
notifying her that Youth A was AWOL.
- Email from Administrator 1 to Foster Care Worker and
Foster Care Supervisor dated August 24, 2025-
Administrator 1 sent an email out letting Foster Care
Worker and Foster Care Supervisor know that Youth A did
not return back to the facility and Youth A’s placement at
the facility was officially closed.
- Phone call screenshots from Case Manager’s phone:
Screen shots of phone calls from Case Manager to Foster
Care Worker were sent to show the communication.
o August 20,2025 11:13am- Case Manager called
Foster Care Worker for 56 seconds to report Youth
A’s AWOL.
o August 20,2025 2:38pm- Case Manager called
Foster Care worker for 1 minute to report Youth A
was spotted at the library by a relative.
o August 25,2025 11:13am- Case Manager called
Foster Care Worker for 45 seconds. It notes Case
Manager spoke with Foster Care to report Relative
had contacted her and let her know Youth A was at
her house. Foster Care Worker expressed, “Thank
you for letting me know.”
- Email from Administrator 3 to Foster Care Worker and
Foster Care Supervisor dated August 22, 2025-
Administrator 3 sent an email to Foster Care Worker and
Foster Care Supervisor noting Youth A has been absent
6

from the facility for three consecutive days. The email also
notes that if Youth A does not return and stay overnight at
the facility and remains absent for a total of five days
through midnight on August 23, 2025, then his bed would
be closed. Administrator 3 attached the bed hold
documentation as well within this email.
- Email from Administrator 3 to Foster Care Worker and
Foster Care Supervisor dated August 24, 2025-
Administrator 3 sent an email to Foster Care Worker and
Foster Care Supervisor that on Friday August 22, 2025,
staff at the facility did see Youth A in the community and
contacted 911 with the update of Youth A’s location. It was
reported staff tried to encourage Youth A to come back but
he refused. The staff did wait for law enforcement to arrive,
which Youth A also refused to go with them as well.
- Email from Licensing Consultant dated September 2,
2025- Licensing Consultant noted he never received
notification of Youth A going AWOL on August 19,2025. It
was noted Administrator 1 did send him an email on August
21, 2025, that was for the incident report of Youth A
returning for a few hours and then leaving again.
- Facility Incident Reporting Policy with the most recent
review date of January 2022- The policy notes, “The
facility will contact the youth’s parents or legal guardian, the
licensing authority, referring agency/youth’s primary
caseworker within 12 hours and provided a written report to
the same parties within 24 hours of any of the following: 4.
If the facility determines that a youth is absent without legal
permission, the facility will report the information to law
enforcement; the parent, legal guardian, or next of kin; the
licensing authority; and the referring agency. The facility will
submit a written report (CIR) to the same parties within 24
hours. Please see AWOLP policy for full instructions.”
- Facility AWLOP Policy with the most recent revision
date of February 2025- This policy notes that if a youth
goes AWOL from the program, then staff are to inform
Administrative Team and on call staff for the program. Staff
are to call law enforcement, and the missing and National
Center Exploited Children Hotline (NCMEC) to report the
youth being AWOL. Staff are then to complete a critical
7

incident report. The Administrative Team will send the
critical incident report to the licensing authority within 24
hours of the youth being AWOL. The Administrative team
are to submit the Critical Incident Report to the youth’s
worker the next business day. It notes within that section
that the email should include: “the youth has 5 days to
return to LTAI from AWLOP. There is a 5-day bed hold for
their youth. After 5 days, the youth’s bed will close at LTAI.”
If a youth Is to return from AWOL, then the staff are to
contact the administrative team, law enforcement, and
NCMEC. The Administrative Team will notify the licensing
authority to report the youth’s return.
- Facility Discharge Policy with the most recent review
date of March 26, 2021- The policy has a section for
unplanned discharges. The policy notes that an unplanned
discharge occurs due to AWOLP, hospitalization, court
order, worker removal, case closure, or death of a resident.
The facility followed protocol for the Youth A being an
unplanned discharge.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance with reporting Youth A’s
AWOL immediately to Foster Care Worker and Licensing
Consultant. The facility’s incident reporting policy noted that
Administrator 1 is to send out the incident report to Foster Care
Worker and Licensing Consultant within 24 hours of the youth
going AWOL. Administrator 1 failed to send out the incident report
in that time frame. This shows that even though the facility’s policy
was not in compliance with the reporting timeframe requirements
per the rule set, Administrator 1 did not report the AWOL in the
time manner required by facility’s policy.
Technical Assistance:
Consultant provided technical assistance to the facility to update
their reporting policy to make sure that all parties required are
notified immediately as noted within the rule. It was suggested that
when the facility reports the youth AWOL to law enforcement that
they should then immediately report the incident to the
parent/legal guardian or next of kin, the licensing authority, and
the referring agency.
Conclusion Violation Established
8

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
